addressleaf.section:
Copie of my letter to yo
r
L.
e 10 of Oc
t
1592.

page.lettertext:
fol.295r
May it please your good L. I was lately re
q
sted to come
to
e assembly of
e
g
na
l states
, where one of them declared
in
e name of
e rest, That they had giv
e
Mons
r
Caron
his dispatche unto her
M
tie
and had
posed by their l
re
s two
special pointes to be considered. One c
o
cerned
e w
t
drawing
of
e c
o
panies fr
o
hens:
t
e C
o
tract thereby was appar
a
tly
infringed: because they have not
t
assistance,
t
was
mised
unto th
e
. They re
q
sted in
e other,
t
some order might
be tak
e
, wherby their trafficke might be freed fr
o
e Englishe
adv
e
turers, by whom
e march
a
ts of these c
o
treis were
notoriously wronged: and
t
restitu
o
n might be made of all
e goods
t
they deteined: namely belonging to
e ship of Tervucel
and to two other ships,
t
have bin tak
e
very lately: of w
c
one
is of
Middelbourgh,
and
e other of
Amsterdame.
In w
c
thre,
as they say, they have lost above
e value of three score thousand
poundes sterling:
e parties being in
England
by wh
o
they
have bin spoiled: charging those ships w
c
were at
e taking
of
e late Indian price: wh
o
they accuse in like maner of
unmercifull tormenting and killing of their mariners: c
o
cluding
in
e end, and
testing
e same very solemnly unto me, that
unles s
o
order might be tak
e
, and
t
very speedely, for
redresse of those enormities, they were sure it would
occasion some great inc
o
venience. For all their march
a
ts
in a maner, not onely in
e townes
t
I m
e
tioned before, but
in sundry other places, did declare very bitterly,
a
d signify
plainely to th
e
,
t
their abilitie would not suffer, nor they
could not have
e patience, to endure those injuries any
longer. Wherup
o
they thought it re
q
sit, not onely to acqua
i
t
me w
t
the effect of their l
re
s, but to intreate me to testify
fol.295v
e disc
o
tentm
t
of
e c
o
trey, and to c
o
curre in
curing some
remedy for it. I
mised in my answear,
both to signify as much as they had re
q
red, and to doe my
best endevour, to advaunce their desires. But yet first for
e point of breaking
e Treaty, I desired to understand, to w
at
effect they would have me, to write unto her M
tie
. If it were
to solicit
e stay of
e c
o
panies, it was to be supposed
t
they were
ether gone alredy or would be gone very shortly: and in all
bability, before it could be possible, to heare out of England.
If their purpose were rather, to have some certaine time
appointed for returne of
e c
o
panies, up
o
intellig
e
ce thereof
I would second it as much, as they could looke for at my
handes. But if they had no other meaning, but to have me
signify in g
na
l,
t
they inter
p
t this employm
t
of
e c
o
panies
in
France,
to be a breache of
e Treaty, it had bin done very
oft
e
, and it was
e argum
t
of their answear of
e 14 of
Sep
t
w
c
I had sent unto her M
tie
. Moreover it would
revive an anci
e
t c
o
tention, about
e keeping of
e C
o
tract,
t
me thought they should desire, to have it put in oblivi
o
.
For if it came in any
q
stion between her Hig
es
and th
e
,
it would be many wayes declared and proved effectually,
t
they had swarved so directly fr
o
e meaning of the
Treaty in a multitude of causes, as it could not be
answeared w
t
any colourable reas
o
. As touching
those abuses
t
were offred to their march
a
ts, I lette
th
e
understand,
t
I had newly receaved a copie of
e
Articles, w
c
M
r
Car
o
their Ag
e
t had exhibited in England,
and had bin lately apostilled by
e Judge of
e Admiralty,
w
c
having delivered to him in this place, I did not
fol.296r
doubt but by him were imparted unto th
e
. And for
ought
t
I could see, their march
a
ts might be satisfied
w
t
those courses of justice
t
had bin used in their affaires.
Nevertheles if they desired some other forme of
ceeding
in
e hearing of their causes, th
e
had bin practised hetherto
and was usual in England, up
o
knowledge in particular,
to what order of dealing they would willingly be subject,
I would not faile, as I might, to recommende it to her M
tie
.
Having made my answear in this sorte, I
might easely
ceave,
t
they stoode at a kinde of stay,
wherof I knew not th
e
e cause. For they replied
but briefly to me, That they had writt
e
to her M
tie
and would leave it so as they had writt
e
, to her M
ts
considerac
o
n. I had confer
e
ce after w
t
M
r
Car
o
, to wh
o
I signified what I had said in
t
meeting of
e States, and how nakedly they spake to
t
w
c
I demanded:
t
I knew not what to thinke of their humours in
e
matters
t
were moved unto me. Wherto he
answeared againe, but under benedicite, That in his
speeches unto th
e
, wh
e
they gave him his dispatche,
he did cast in a maner
e self same doubtes, and
desired to be informed of their full resolu
o
n, as well
for re
q
ring
e c
o
panies againe, as for some order of
ceeding in
e affaires of
e march
a
ts. W
t
all he
shewed the
e forme of a certaine c
o
mission, w
c
was
graunted by her M
tie
e 25 of her raigne, to certaine
of my
LL. of
e Privy Counsel
, together w
t
some others,
to examine and determine all causes of
t
qualitie,
t
should touche any subject of
e
King of Scotland
.
fol.296v
And if they would be c
o
tented to accept of
e like, he
suaded th
e
to thinke,
t
it should not be denied.
To this they told him againe,
t
first for
e mater of
e
Englishe c
o
panies, he should by no meanes be instant, to
have th
e
sent againe hither, but onely in g
na
l termes make
remonstr
a
ce of their grief, in
t
e Treaty was neglected.
And for
e causes of
e march
a
ts, they did not seeme to
dislike of
t
ceeding by way of c
o
mission: but yet they
would not of themselves become suitours to have it. Because
they thought by
t
meanes they might be overmuch bound
and admitte an ill
p
sid
e
t in referring
e decisi
o
of their
causes into England. Of this I thought very fitte
to advertise your L. Yet because it will turne M
r
Car
o
to displeasure, if
e States should understand it, and he
would not greatly like
t
I should write it to your L.
I would willingly c
o
mitte it as a secret to your self.
I had very litle hope
t
e States would have used his
service any longer. For it is not for love
t
is bearen
unto him by
e principal heere, nor for any good liking
t
they have of his dealing: because they judge him to be
partiall, and to much addicted to her M
ts
designes. But they
c
a
hardly finde an other,
t
is both suffici
e
t for
e place,
and a m
a
of
t
carriage, as is meete for th
e
to send to
negociat w
t
her M
tie
. What int
e
ti
o
they may have,
in forbidding him expressely to make any sute unto her M
tie
to returne her assistance, I c
a
not yet c
o
jecture. For
e
people of this c
o
trey are diversely affected. Some would
suade to have her M
tie
moved to assiste th
e
for heerafter
in some other kinde of sort: as by an
a
nual s
o
me of money:
fol.297r
wherby their turne might be served, if
e s
u
me were c
o
ptet
e
t,
to better purpose then before. Others doe desire
e c
o
tinu
a
ce
of
e succours, but yet because they doe see
e F
r
Kinges
necessity, w
c
they know must be relieved by her M
tie
or by th
e
,
they are not much unwilling to their imploym
t
in
Brittaine:
supposing
t
her M
tie
being once embarked in
t
warre, will
maintaine it so roundely, as this c
o
trey will be eased in their
im
p
sts to
e King. Some others thinke
t
e c
o
trey is so
assured in every Province, as there is no necessitie of her Ma
ties
support. And to
e end they might enjoye their gouvernm
t
alone, and be quite of
e authoritie w
c
is due unto her
by
e C
o
tract, they would gladdly be ridde of all
e Englishe
nation. Whether of these c
o
ceates is in
e Deputies
heere of
e g
na
l States, I c
a
not say w
t
any certainty.
But once I am assured,
t
howsoever their estate and
e
qualitie of their
sones doth minister cause to make
m
e
thinke
t
their dealinges are as plaine and inwardly
e same, as they are caried in outward shew, yet to say
as I finde by their daily
ceeding, they are many of th
e
wily and voide of sinceritie, ill affected in their heartes,
and unthankfull towardes her M
tie
. And whether
it be not needfull in
t
respect, and for their p
nt
doubtfull dealing,
t
some extraordinary care
should be tak
e
of
e cautionary townes, I know your
L. will consider. So much
e more for
t
e c
o
trey
at this p
nt
is greatly dis
q
eted w
t
these tidinges of the
torture and slaughter of their seam
e
and continu
a
ce
of their losses, w
c
are
a
plified allwayes by
e march
a
ts
report, and
e people made beleve,
t
ether in England
fol.297v
they c
a
not be heard, or
t
they c
a
not have justice.
Which I know doth
ceede of very passi
o
and malice,
through
e losse of their goods, but yet undoubtedly
heere, it is both a comon speeche and a c
o
st
a
t
suasion,
aswell of
e chiefe as of
e vulgar sort of people: that
unles they may receave some speedy satisfacti
o
, it c
a
not choose but engender some dangerous disorder.
And how soone it may be wrought by
e meanes of badde
instrum
ts
of w
c
these c
o
treis have enough, I neede not
signify to your L. It is written
fr
o
Brussels,
t
e
King of Spaine
doth determine
to send thither his
sonne,
to
e ende
e people of those
Provinces may publickly accept him as lawfull heir
unto his father, and take an othe of obedience.
They signify w
t
all,
t
there is a model sent thither
for enlarging
e palace: w
c
is also begonne and in
hand already. This is thought to be a practise,
not onely to c
o
tene his
one
owne
in devotion, but by some
offers to c
o
passe
e disuniting of these contreis.
Where it hath bin heere c
o
cluded,
t
their army yet in field, should passe
e Rhine about
Embricke, to stoppe
e passage of
e Enemy: it was
p
nt
ly after understood,
t
600 horse of
e Enemies
strength were over already: and
t
e
Duke
in like
maner was gone fr
o
e Spa: wherup
o
Counte
Maurice
w
t
his campe attendeth about Embricke,
to see what
Verdugo
will further attempt w
t
the
remainder of his forces: who we heare at this
p
nt
, doth not sturre out of
Oldenzeel
in
e
Twente,
fol.278r
having lost in a mutin i e, for w
at
of pay, 7 enseignes
of footm
e
, w
c
are wholy debanded, and 5 cornets of
horse,
t
are passed
e Rhine. It is said therup
o
t
Count Maurice is gone to doe some exploite: but
whether it be to fight w
t
Verdugo, while his souldiours
doe mutine, or to attempt somewhat els, it is not
certified unto us. But unles it be to surprise some
place of
e Enemy, or to doe some soddaine service by way
of incursion,
e yere is so much spent, and heere
hath fall
e
so much rain for two moneths together,
t
it is not possible for
e souldiours to keepe
e field
any longer in a contrey full of marishes.
And so
I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage. Oc
t
10 1592.
